awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Next Generation Nanomaterial and Device Engineering (NGeNE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The mission of the proposed Next Generation Nanomaterial and Device Engineering (NGeNE)  center is to develop a science, engineering, and technology base for the rational  design of next generation computers, starting from their underlying material embodiments and fundamental physical principles. To build a chip for information 
processing, we must explore nanoscale logic and memory, photonics for high speed on-chip communication  and thermal engineering to handle energy  dissipation in 3D. The NGeNE center will address all these components, along with computational modeling, scientific training and education. 
Various industrial sectors such as the semiconductor chip industry, optoelectronics, mobile and wireless technology, energy, photonics, chemical, biological and packaging industry, as well as the civilian and defense infrastructure, healthcare and the energy sector will directly benefit from this effort. The goal of the center will be to (a) form a critical University Industry Government nexus on emerging nanotechnology, (b) carry out industry relevant research using state of the art modeling, simulation, growth, characterization, fabrication and integration of 
emerging nanomaterials and devices, (c) provide a competitive edge to industry and national labs by leveraging the multi-university intellectual resources for cost effective innovative solutions to their current problems, and (d) develop  supporting curricula, create databases and train students and industry affiliates with the tools and knowledge infrastructure to meet their future work force requirements.

The proposed center for Next Generation Nanomaterial and Device Engineering (NGeNE) aims to form a University-Industry-Government (UIG) nexus  towards the design and engineering of next generation nanomaterials and devices 
with an emphasis on post-CMOS computing. This will rest on four pillars: Nanoelectronics and NanoMagnetism for Logic and Memory (Computation),  Thermal for power management, and Photonics for on chip communication. The research thrusts span a large phase space from novel switching schemes to non-Boolean logic, beyond silicon to advanced magnetic, thermal and photonic materials.  They combine physical models with computational software, compact models and architecture, heterogeneous growth and integration, nanofabrication, characterization, testing and reliability. The goal of the center will be to (a) form a critical University Industry Government nexus on emerging nanotechnology, (b) carry out industry relevant research using state of the art modeling, simulation, growth, characterization, fabrication and integration of emerging nanomaterials and devices, (c) provide a competitive edge to industry and national labs by leveraging the multi-university intellectual resources for cost effective innovative solutions to their current problems, and (d) develop supporting curricula, create databases and train students and industry affiliates with the tools and knowledge infrastructure to meet their future work force requirements.

por.por_cntn:
The original goal of the planning grant was to execute a planning meeting to establish an NSF-I/UCRC center entitled, “IUCRC Next Generation Nanomaterial and Device Engineering (NGeNE)” between three schools: University of Virginia, Virginia Tech and Penn State, with an emphasis on emerging, beyond complementary metal oxide semiconductor (post CMOS) computing. Subsequently, after discussions with NSF and with the "IUCRC Center for Multifunctional Integrated Systems Technology (MIST)", our focus shifted to establishing a single site addition at UVA to the existing MIST center, and the rest of the planning grant funds were redirected towards recruiting for the new site. 

Planning meeting was held on September 28-29, 2015 at UVA for the NGeNE center. There were approximately 90 total attendees, including 36 external guests from 35 different companies, 7 external guests from 6 different government agencies, 4 NSF representatives, 25 NGeNE Faculty (12 from UVA, 5 from PSU, 8 from VaTech) + 4 UVA administrators and 22 NGeNE Students (15 UVA, 4 PSU, 3 VaTech).  11 posters were presented in an evening poster session, while 13 project proposals were presented at the Planning Meeting with LIFEFORM feedback. 6 other supplementary projects were circulated by email and electronic media distributed at the meeting after we got feedback from the attending company representatives. 

After discussions with NSF and MIST leadership following the planning meeting, NGeNE leadership at UVA felt that it is in our best interests to combine our efforts, given the perceived overlap between our teams, while still retaining enough complementarity to add value to UF/UCF. Specifically, UVA adds new expertise to the MIST center in functional materials (oxides and 2D), solid-state devices, photonics, RF/microwave/THz, imaging, thermal characterization, multiscale modeling and heterogeneous integration. In addition, UVA expands the MIST scope of system applications by expanding to photonic systems and high-performance electronics. UVA’s portfolio will help attract new members and/or bolster certain industry sectors such as military/defense, healthcare and the semiconductor industry. In addition, it is anticipated that UVA's location will help the MIST center expand its influence to the Washington DC belt, where there is a high concentration of potential members, especially in the defense and healthcare sectors. UVA joining will broaden the geographical presence of the MIST Center out of Florida and along the eastern seaboard of the US. 

After the discussions, MIST leadership visited UVA on March 29, 2016 to describe their center vision, bylaws, emphasis areas, operating principles and best practices. Subsequently, UVA leadership visited the MIST-IAB meeting in Orlando on May 3 2016, to present our vision, following which the existing MIST IAB and leadership unanimously voted to invite us to join MIST as a site. 

With the expanded scope of our original NGeNE plan, and the single site focus at UVA, we organized a second, focused planning meeting at UVA on Dec 12 2016, to reintroduce the members to the expanded MIST goals as opposed to the original NGeNE goals. This meeting proved very productive, as we managed to recruit 5 organizations shortly after the meeting and submit our full proposal. 

In addition to this focused recruitment effort, we have had ongoing recruitment efforts. Ghosh secured an internal SEAS R&I grant to supplement the NSF grant, allowing us to do more expanded travel. Through these joint efforts, Ghosh visited Night Vision Labs, Mitre, ORNL, NRL and ARL, and had multiple telecons with NGC, HGST/WD, and discussions with Intel, IBM, Global Foundries and Micron at Albany. Of these, Night Vision and ARL are already on board. NGC, Mitre and HGST/WD are potentially interested. NRL, ORNL are unsure about whether their funding mechanism through Basic Energy would allow participation. Intel, IBM, GF and Micron typically fund through SRC, but this mechanism is seemingly difficult for the NSF policy on consortia - so we are trying to address them individually outside the SRC. They are potentially interested, but have not figured out a funding mechanism so far. 

In addition, co-PIs Hopkins, Stan and Beling have made multiple visits to introduce MIST goals to other potential industry partners at various symposia/meetings. 

Multiple students/post-docs were involved in organizing the planning meetings, and presenting their work through posters and presentations. They were also involved in various parts of the grant writing process. This is critical learning experience for students/postdocs interested in academic jobs.
